title: Geostationary Orbit

children.value: A satellite is to be placed in a circular orbit around the Earth.

Use the information and data below to calculate the required radius of the orbit if the satellite is in a geostationary orbit (remains above the same point on the equator). Please give your answer to two significant figures.

answer.value:
The orbit of the satellite must have a radius of 
$\valuedef{r}{4.2\times 10^7}{m}$
.

children.value:
The gravitational force $\vari{F_{A}}$ between the satellite and the Earth is in the inward radial direction and its magnitude is given by the equation

$\displaystyle F_ A=GMm/R^2 $

where $\vari{G}$ is the gravitational constant; $\vari{M}$ and $\vari{m}$ are the masses of the Earth and the satellite respectively; and $\vari{R}$ is the radius of the orbit.
